analysis: The documents all pertain to the extension of trust periods on land allotments made to Native American individuals and tribes. These extensions prevent the alienation of these lands, ensuring they remain under federal protection for a specified duration. The documents cite various acts of Congress as the legal basis for these extensions, including the Dawes Act of 1887 and the Act of June 21, 1906. The extensions vary in length, typically ranging from 10 to 25 years. Some orders apply to specific tribes or reservations, while others have broader application. A recurring theme is the protection of Native American land rights and the federal government's role in this protection.
title: Native American Land Trust Extensions
